Comment: Thank fuck I filed a couple months ago (spousal AOS).   Re: Asylum fees. There’s no good way to do this without congressional funding. USCIS is 100% fee funded. Under Biden’s DHS, there was a massive reorientation towards humanitarian and asylum based immigration. These applicants do not pay any fees (generally) and are tremendously expensive as they typically require substantially more USCIS staff time (on top of judicial oversight). As a result, all other applicants foot the bill, so to speak. Fees went up and processing time continued to climb. The majority of asylum applications do end up being denied. Whether you agree with it or not, the number of DHS asylum, protection, and humanitarian-related claims per year vastly exceeded pretty much every single other category. Just asylum alone saw more applicants than spousal, other family, and work based *COMBINED* at just shy of 500,000. This is obviously tremendously expensive and the money has to cost from somewhere. The number of asylum applications has exploded. 2000-2023 average was 90,000. 2024 was 480,000.   For context, it cost $3300+$5,500 in legal fees to file all of my paperwork (I-130, I-485, I-131, and I-797).

Comment: Coming at it from the perspective of someone who is going through the legal immigration process: The asylum system is causing enormous problems right now and needs to be reformed. Badly.   Asylum seekers currently do not pay fees. They are also the most costly (Ie, requiring the most resources from USCIS) class of immigrant. 2000-2023 the annual average was 90,000 applicants. 2024 saw 480,000 applicants. That’s more than any other immigrant visa class. That’s actually more than all other classes (work and family) *combined*. Approval rates have dropped to around 30-35% and is continuing to drop for myriad reasons.   USCIS is not congressionally funded. It’s 100% fee funded. Without congressional funding, all other applicants are seeing skyrocketing fees and dizzying application times. Between 2019 and 2024, form I-130 saw processing times increase by 100%.  While I’m not suggesting what is being proposed is good, the current system is completely unsustainable. A minority of applicants are wholly paying for the fees of the majority, who are seeing their forms processed at a faster rate compared to those who are paying. Asylum EAD processing time is 2-4 weeks. I-485 AOS EAD processing time is 3-4 months.  It was ~$3,300 to file all of my paperwork. $9,000 including legal fees.   > would have to pay a $550 fee when applying for authorization to work  That is approximately how much I paid to file for EAD ($520). It would just be removing the exemption. This is just the reality of finite resources being need to accommodate hundreds of thousands of people who do not pay into that pool of resources. You either accept this, or let all other applicants continue to pay for higher fees with longer processing times. Keep in mind, the overwhelming majority of green card applicants are also from poor countries. Fees were already hiked drastically under Biden, and processing time continued to spiral out of control.
